summary: Email chain regarding the submission and review of an application for a search warrant in the Epstein case. The chain includes a clerk transmitting a signed warrant, and earlier correspondence where a judge identifies a date error in the application (referring to Epstein's arrest in July 2020, which had not yet occurred).

persons.name: Vincent Babino
persons.context: Clerk at the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York who sends the signed search warrant via email.

persons.name: Gabriel Gorenstein
persons.context: United States District Judge who reviews the search warrant application, identifies a date error, and arranges a call with the prosecutor and agent.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The individual whose arrest is referenced in the search warrant application; the subject of the investigation.

connections.description: Judge Gorenstein reviews and provides feedback on the search warrant application submitted by the AUSA.
Babino, as a court clerk, transmits the signed warrant following Judge Gorenstein's review process.

events.title: Search Warrant Application Review
events.description: Judge Gabriel Gorenstein reviews the search warrant application materials, identifies an error regarding the date of Jeffrey Epstein's arrest, and schedules a call with the prosecutor and agent.

events.title: Search Warrant Signed
events.description: The signed search warrant is transmitted by court clerk Vincent Babino following the judge's review.

events.title: Referenced Epstein Arrest Date
events.description: The search warrant application incorrectly references Jeffrey Epstein's arrest as occurring on July 6, 2020. Judge Gorenstein notes this error, as the arrest had already occurred in 2019.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York, 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY 10007
1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: A search warrant application in the Epstein case contained a significant date error, stating Epstein was arrested on July 6, 2020, when his arrest occurred in July 2019.
Judge Gabriel Gorenstein identified the error but noted it did not affect the probable cause for the warrant.
The email chain shows the procedural steps for obtaining a search warrant, including judge review, correction submission, and final transmission by a court clerk.
